sentences: Goo Hara (; January 3, 1991 – November 24, 2019), also known mononymously as Hara, was a South Korean singer and actress.
section: N/A

sentences: She was a member of the South Korean girl group Kara, and had also appeared in television dramas including City Hunter (2011).
section: N/A

sentences: She made her debut as a soloist in July 2015 with the release of her EP Alohara (Can You Feel It?).
section: N/A

sentences: After Kara disbanded in 2016, she continued her solo career at another agency, KeyEast.
section: N/A

sentences: Her solo career was interrupted in 2018 after she became embroiled in a legal case with her ex-boyfriend, Choi Jong-Bum, which was initiated when he assaulted Goo and threatened to release their sex video to harm her career.
section: N/A

sentences: In June 2019, she continued her solo activities in Japan where she was well-received by fans.
section: N/A

sentences: Her last release was a maxi single "Midnight Queen", released on September 19, 2019.
section: N/A

sentences: Goo's death, ruled as a possible suicide on November 24, 2019, brought worldwide attention to sexual crimes against women in South Korea, one of which was the usage of molka (spy cameras) to discreetly capture voyeuristic images and videos of women.
section: N/A

sentences: In response several petitions were submitted to the Blue House.
section: N/A

sentences: One petition demanded a more severe punishment for filming sexual acts without consent and distributing it, and the other represented a need to revise South Korea's inheritance laws to prevent absent parents from claiming inheritance from their neglected children.
section: N/A

sentences: The inheritance laws were amended on December 1, 2020, with the bill carrying amendments titled "Goo Hara Act".
section: N/A

sentences: As the amended law could not be applied retrospectively, Goo's brother Goo Ho-in filed a lawsuit against their mother, who was said to have neglected her parental duties, to prevent her from claiming inheritance from Goo Hara's estate.
section: N/A

sentences: The court awarded their mother 40% of the estate.
section: N/A
== Life and career ==

sentences: Life and career ==
section: == Life and career ==
== Life and career == | === Early life and education ===

sentences: Early life and education
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and education ===
== Life and career == | === Early life and education ===

sentences: Goo was born on January 3, 1991, in Gwangju, South Korea.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and education ===

sentences: Goo's parents separated when she was eight years old after her mother abandoned the family.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and education ===

sentences: Goo and her brother were raised by their grandmother while their father was working as a construction worker around the country to support the family.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and education ===

sentences: She attended Woonchun Elementary School and Jeonnam Middle School, and trained as a track and field athlete for two years.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and education ===

sentences: Goo came to Seoul while attending Jeonju Fine Arts High School and participated in SM Entertainment's youth appearance tournament in 2005.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and education ===

sentences: She later transferred to Dongmyung Girls' Information Industry High School and then attended Sungshin Women's University.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and education ===

sentences: During her school days, she worked as a model for internet clothing stores.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and education ===

sentences: In 2007, she unsuccessfully auditioned to join JYP Entertainment.
section: == Life and career == | === Early life and education ===
== Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===
== Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: Kara ===
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: Goo joined the girl group Kara in 2008, following the departure of former member Kim Sung-hee.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: In October 2009, she became a cast member of the KBS reality show Invincible Youth.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: On January 5, 2010, during an appearance on the SBS reality show Strong Heart, Goo admitted that she had had dental and minor facial cosmetic surgery.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: She stated that she had always had double eyelids, but had surgery to make them more defined.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: In 2011, Goo made her acting debut in SBS City Hunter, where she starred as Choi Da-hye, the daughter of South Korea's president.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: On January 19, 2011, it was announced that Goo would be terminating her contract with her label DSP Media along with three other members of Kara, and a lawsuit was filed on their behalf.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: Later that day, it was announced that she would discontinue her involvement with the suit and had rejoined the company, as she apparently was not fully aware of the lawsuit's details.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: In November 2011, she and Nicole Jung (a fellow member of Kara) became the new MCs for Inkigayo, and they left the show on August 19, 2012 to focus on Kara's comeback.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: In 2013, Goo collaborated with Japanese musician and songwriter Masaharu Fukuyama to record a song called "Magic of Love" in Korean under the project group, Hara+.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: The song was used as a soundtrack for FujiTV's drama Galileo, in which Fukuyama starred.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: In October 2013, she was appointed as the blood donation ambassador for the Hanmaum Blood Bank.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: On December 29, 2014, she appeared in her own reality show titled On & Off, which aired on MBC Music.
section: == Life and career == | === 2008–2015: Kara ===

sentences: Alohara (Can You Feel It)
section: == Life and career == | ==== Alohara (Can You Feel It) ====
== Life and career == | ==== Alohara (Can You Feel It) ====

sentences: In January 2015, Goo started hosting KBS' idol beauty show A Style For You along with Super Junior's Kim Heechul, EXID's Hani and Sistar's Bora.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Alohara (Can You Feel It) ====

sentences: In June 2015, she released a beauty book titled Nail Hara.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Alohara (Can You Feel It) ====

sentences: In July 2015, Goo debuted as a solo artist with the release of the EP Alohara (Can You Feel It?), which peaked at #4 domestically.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Alohara (Can You Feel It) ====

sentences: The lead single "Choco Chip Cookies" features South Korean rapper Giriboy.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Alohara (Can You Feel It) ====

sentences: In October 2015, Goo joined the variety show Shaolin Clenched Fists.
section: == Life and career == | ==== Alohara (Can You Feel It) ====
== Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: 2016–2019: Final projects before death =
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===
== Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: On January 15, 2016, Kara disbanded due to Goo and fellow members Park Gyu-ri and Han Seung-yeon leaving DSP Media upon the expiration of their contracts with the company.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: Goo then signed with KeyEast a few days later to pursue a solo career.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: In December 2016, she featured in Thunder's single, "Sign".
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: In August 2017, Goo starred in a web movie titled Sound of a Footstep.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: In November 2017, she joined the variety show Seoul Mate.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: In January 2018, Goo released a soundtrack for the drama Jugglers, titled "On A Good Day".
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: In April 2018, she hosted the JTBC's beauty show My Mad Beauty Diary.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: In July, she was named honorary ambassador for the 6th Animal Film Festival.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: In August 2018, Goo debuted as a soloist in Japan, releasing the song "Wild".
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: Beginning in October 2018, Goo and her ex-boyfriend, Choi Jong-bum, became involved in a legal dispute that extended into 2019.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: The nature of the dispute caused issues in both her professional and personal life, including Content Y (a subsidiary of KeyEast that Goo had been actively promoting under since 2017), declining to renew her contract following its expiration in January 2019.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: After being on hiatus for the first half of 2019, Goo announced in June 2019 that she had signed with Production Ogi to continue her activities in Japan.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: Goo had previously enjoyed popularity in Japan when Kara was still active and being promoted in Japan, having participated in 62nd NHK Kōhaku Uta Gassen.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: Goo's final release prior to her death was the maxi single "Midnight Queen", which was released in September 2019.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: She also embarked on a mini tour, titled Hara Zepp Tour 2019:
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: Hello, to support the album.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: The tour consisted of four concert dates held across Japan in November 2019, ending on the 19th.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: Goo had a successful solo career in Japan and was well received by her Japanese fans during the mini tour.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: On January 12, 2020, the music video for "Hello", a B-side track from "Midnight Queen", was released posthumously.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: Its lyrics were penned by Goo to thank her supporters, and the video featured her against the night-time cityscape of Tokyo, which she had loved.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===

sentences: As a follow up to the music video, a photobook, memorializing Goo with photos taken just before her death, was released posthumously on April 6, 2020.
section: == Life and career == | === 2016–2019: Final projects before death ===
== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==
== Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum =
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===
== Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: Goo dated hairdresser Choi Jong-Bum after the two first met on the set of the beauty TV program My Mad Beauty Diary.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: At around 1 a.m. of September 13, 2018, a drunken Choi broke into Goo's house while she was sleeping and started an argument that escalated into violent assault, when he allegedly tried to break up with her.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: The police arrived at Goo's house after Choi reported her for assault.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: Goo claimed that the incident was two-sided and then both parties posted images of their injuries to the internet to explain their side of the story.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: After the incident, Goo underwent a medical examination, and she was found to be suffering from uterus and vagina hemorrhage, and was also diagnosed with "cervical sprain", "facial contusions and sprain", "lower leg contusions and sprain", and "right forearm and additional sprains."
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: Following this, Goo filed a lawsuit against Choi for threatening to release a sex video filmed without her consent in an attempt by him to end her career.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: In the first trial session held on April 18, 2019, Choi was presented with the charges of filming the sex video, injury, intimidation, coercion, and property damage.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: Choi denied all charges except destruction of property.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: On May 26, 2019, Goo attempted suicide in her apartment and was immediately taken to the hospital, after which she apologized for worrying her fans.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: As a result, Goo did not attend the second trial session on May 30, 2019.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: She was originally scheduled to appear as a witness in court.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: In the third trial session on July 18, 2019 the presiding judge, Oh Duk-Shik, requested that the video be submitted as evidence to the court as the content in the video was disputed.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: After objections from Goo's lawyers over the possibility that the public might view the video in court, the judge viewed the video privately in his chamber to confirm the content of the video.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: Additionally, Goo testified to Oh in private for two hours as well.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: In August 2019, Choi was acquitted of the charge of filming the sex video without permission as the court agreed that the filming was done without her consent, but because she remained in the relationship they found him not guilty of illicit filming.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: However, he was sentenced to one year and six months in prison, suspended for three years after probation, after being convicted of threatening to upload the sex video, coercion, physical assault, and destroying Goo's property.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: After news of her sex video went public, Goo was harassed online on social media, despite being the victim of a crime.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: Upon closure of an appeal to the suspended sentence on July 2, 2020, Choi was sentenced to a year in prison, with the court stating that Choi "was well aware that the degree of damage would be very serious if the sex videos were leaked, given that the victim was a famous celebrity".
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: The prosecution team appealed to the Supreme Court for a heavier sentence on July 8, 2020.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: On September 23, Choi applied for bail while awaiting for the decision from the Supreme Court over the prosecution's appeal that was set for October 15.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: The Supreme Court denied his bail stating, "There is no significant reason to grant bail for Choi Jong-Bum.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: This decision was made with the consensus of the Supreme Court Justices involved."
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===

sentences: The Supreme Court upheld the one-year sentence on October 15, 2020.
section: == Personal life == | === Domestic dispute with Choi Jong-Bum ===
== Personal life == | === Death, investigation and commemoration ===

sentences: Death, investigation and commemoration ===
section: == Personal life == | === Death, investigation and commemoration ===

sentences: On November 24, 2019, Hara was found dead at her home in Cheongdam-dong, Gangnam by her manager, with the cause of death ruled as a possible suicide.
section: == Personal life == | === Death, investigation and commemoration ===

sentences: Police found a suicide note written by Goo, and concluded that there was no foul play, as she was seen on CCTV footage returning home at 12:40 am, with no further visitors except for the housekeeper who found her body at 6 p.m. the same day.
section: == Personal life == | === Death, investigation and commemoration ===

sentences: An autopsy was not performed after the police consulted the prosecutor in-charge and took into consideration her family's request.
section: == Personal life == | === Death, investigation and commemoration ===

sentences: The body was handed over to her family on November 26.
section: == Personal life == | === Death, investigation and commemoration ===

sentences: Goo's death occurred over a month after her close friend and fellow idol Sulli had committed suicide.
section: == Personal life == | === Death, investigation and commemoration ===

sentences: Goo's funeral was privately held at Gangnam Severance Hospital by family members and friends, while a separate memorial service for fans took place on November 25–26 in The Catholic University of Korea Seoul St. Mary's Hospital in Gangnam.
section: == Personal life == | === Death, investigation and commemoration ===

sentences: On November 27, Goo's body was cremated and her remains were enshrined at the Skycastle Memorial Park in Bundang, Gyeonggi-do.
section: == Personal life == | === Death, investigation and commemoration ===
== Legacy ==

sentences: Legacy ==
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Her death brought worldwide attention to sexual crimes against women in South Korea.
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Following her death, a petition was submitted to the Blue House with over 200,000 signatures demanding a more severe punishment for filming sexual acts without consent and distributing it.
section: == Legacy ==

sentences: Moreover, it was revealed that Goo had helped reporter Kang Kyung-yoon investigate Jung Joon-young's chatroom case prior to her death.
section: == Legacy ==
== Legacy == | === Petition to revise inheritance law and the Goo Hara Act ===

sentences: Petition to revise inheritance law and the Goo Hara Act ===
section: == Legacy == | === Petition to revise inheritance law and the Goo Hara Act ===

sentences: Goo Hara's elder brother, Goo Ho-in, started a petition to revise South Korea's inheritance law, to prevent a parent from claiming inheritance if they had neglected their parental duties, after being contacted by their estranged mother for a share of Goo Hara's inheritance.
section: == Legacy == | === Petition to revise inheritance law and the Goo Hara Act ===

sentences: The petition was successful, after gathering 100,000 signatures in 30 days.
section: == Legacy == | === Petition to revise inheritance law and the Goo Hara Act ===

sentences: Goo Ho-in then pushed the legislature to introduce the law in Goo Hara's name, as the Goo Hara Act.
section: == Legacy == | === Petition to revise inheritance law and the Goo Hara Act ===

sentences: However, the bill failed to pass in the 20th National Assembly, claiming that it needed further review.
section: == Legacy == | === Petition to revise inheritance law and the Goo Hara Act ===

sentences: The 21st National Assembly continued to look into the prospective law.
section: == Legacy == | === Petition to revise inheritance law and the Goo Hara Act ===

sentences: At the plenary session held on December 1, 2020, the revised law was passed by the 21st National Assembly, along with other unrelated bills.
section: == Legacy == | === Petition to revise inheritance law and the Goo Hara Act ===
== Legacy == | === Inheritance lawsuit ===

sentences: Inheritance lawsuit =
section: == Legacy == | === Inheritance lawsuit ===
== Legacy == | === Inheritance lawsuit ===

sentences: Goo Ho-in also filed a lawsuit to prevent their mother from seeking 50% of Goo Hara's assets as inheritance, as she reportedly did not fulfill her parental duties to the siblings.
section: == Legacy == | === Inheritance lawsuit ===

sentences: The revised law would not be applicable against their mother's claim, due to another law preventing retrospective application of new laws on old cases.
section: == Legacy == | === Inheritance lawsuit ===

sentences: Their father passed his claim of the inheritance to Goo Ho-in.
section: == Legacy == | === Inheritance lawsuit ===

sentences: On December 22, 2020, the Gwangju Family Court ruled that their mother would receive 40% of the inheritance while Goo Ho-in would receive the remaining 60%.
section: == Legacy == | === Inheritance lawsuit ===
== Legacy == | === Fundraiser for single parent families ===

sentences: Fundraiser for single parent families =
section: == Legacy == | === Fundraiser for single parent families ===
== Legacy == | === Fundraiser for single parent families ===

sentences: On the second anniversary of Goo Hara's death in 2021, Goo Ho-in announced that he would auction 10 oil paintings done by Goo Hara of which proceeds would partially be donated to a Japanese non-profit organisation, Florence, whose primary clients are of single parent families.
section: == Legacy == | === Fundraiser for single parent families ===
